prompt.p: A 64-year-old man with acromegaly presents complaining of severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting exacerbated by food. On examination he is haemodynamically stable. There are no chest signs. His abdomen is soft with mild tenderness in his right upper quadrant. Haematological investigation:
What medication is the cause of the patient's presentation?

modalFeedback.p: Option D (Octreotide) is Correct. Octreotide is used in acromegaly or down regulation of the exocrine pancreas after pancreatic surgery. This somatostatin analogue causes cholelithiasis and can result in gallstone formation.
Option A (Alendronate) is Incorrect. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that is used in osteoporosis. Tablets can cause erosion of the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. oesophagitis or gastric ulceration.

Option B (Carbimazole) is Incorrect. Agranulocytosis is a complication of Carbimazole, used to treat hyperthyroidism. Patients are warned to seek medical attention if they become ill with symptoms and sign of infection.

Option C (Metformin) is Incorrect. Metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis which requires withdrawal of this treatment. It can occur in the presence of renal impairment, dehydration, shock, infection or myocardial infarction.
Option E (Thyroxine) is Incorrect. Levothyroxine can cause symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis.
